Honestly? I don't think so, and that's part of the problem. The second you suggest that maybe unlimited camping isn't actually helping people, you get labeled as heartless or classist or whatever. People would rather feel good about their "compassionate" positions than actually look at what works.

Like, I've tried having this conversation with friends who are all about "housing first" and "decriminalization," and they just shut down when I mention what I've seen at the shelter. They act like I've been brainwashed by some right-wing propaganda instead of just... observing reality.

And don't get me started on city council meetings. I went to one where they were debating these camping ordinances, and it was just person after person getting up to talk about "criminalizing poverty" and "systemic injustice." Which, fine, those are real issues. But when someone like me tries to talk about actual safety concerns or what shelter workers say actually helps people, suddenly I'm the villain.

It's like there's this weird moral hierarchy where if you're not advocating for the most permissive possible approach, you're automatically a bad person. But meanwhile, the people stuck in these camps aren't getting better, the neighborhoods are getting worse, and nothing actually changes except everyone gets to feel righteous about their positions.

That cop probably thinks he's being the good guy here, but he's just another person choosing what makes him feel good over what might actually work. And when it all falls apart, he won't be the one dealing with the consequences - it'll be people like my elderly neighbor and that coffee shop owner.

<END>
